People -- African Americans

note.p: Alexander K. Davis was a representative in the Mississippi legislature and served as the state’s lieutenant governor from 1874 to 1876, during Reconstruction. He was the first African American lieutenant governor of Mississippi.

Little was recorded of Davis’ past. His date and place of birth are not known. During testimony before Congress in 1871 he explained that he moved to Noxubee County, Mississippi, from Tennessee in 1869, and said he had been admitted to the bar (a reference that he had been accepted as a practicing attorney in a city or county), but did not specify in which state. He won a seat in Mississippi’s House of Representatives shortly after coming to Mississippi and became a leading figure in the state’s Republican Party circles. In 1873, Radical Republicans backed by a majority of African American voters in Mississippi, won a series of state elections. Davis was one of three African Americans elected to statewide office that year, winning the lieutenant governor seat. (The other Black figures to win statewide election were James Hill as secretary of state and T. W. Cardozo as state superintendent of education.) The following year, white conservatives carried out a campaign of intimidation and violence to suppress Republican and African American voting and put Democrats into political power. The effort worked and by 1875, Democrats held a majority of state legislative seats. Emboldened by their political power, Democrats tried to rid Republicans from many state positions. They specifically targeted Davis and northern-born and Radical Republican Governor Adelbert Ames, accusing both men of improprieties in office. Davis was charged with illegal granting of pardons. Despite his effort to fight the trumped-up charges, Mississippi Democrats impeached Davis in March 1876. Knowing that the conviction would result in him being removed from office, Davis resigned. Governor Ames, also facing politically-driven impeachment proceedings that would require extensive time and financial resources to fight, resigned as well. Following his resignation, Davis abandoned politics. He moved to Canton, Mississippi and worked as a pastor. He died on November 21, 1884.
(Wikipedia; Dernoral Davis, "Alexander K. Davis," Mississippi Encyclopedia; Clyde Tucker, “Alexander K. Davis (?-1884),” Black Past)
Alexander Kelso Davis belonged to the following social groups:
Richard Coke was an attorney and politician who served as a U.S. Senator and governor of Texas in the nineteenth century.

Born on March 18, 1829, in Williamsburg, Virginia, Coke graduated from the College of William and Mary in 1848 and moved to Waco, Texas, in 1850 to practice law. His law firm prospered and Coke purchased land and slaves to expand his wealth and prominence. By the late 1850s he was active in state government matters, including serving on a Texas commission to oversee the removal the Comanche tribe from portions of Texas in 1859. In 1861, he won election to be a delegate to Texas’s secession convention and voted in favor of the state separating from the Union. After the Civil War broke out, Coke raised a company of volunteers that was integrated into the Fifteenth Texas Infantry Regiment. He served as an officer in the regiment and was wounded in the Battle of Bayou Bourbeau in November 1863.

Immediately following the Civil War, Coke returned to Texas and received an appointment as a district court judge. Only a year later, in 1866, he was elected to be an associate justice on the Texas Supreme Court. However, federal authorities removed Coke and four other justices due to their opposition to Reconstruction. The removal boosted Coke’s standing among conservative whites in Texas. He successfully ran for governor as a Democrat in December 1873. The Texas Supreme Court ruled the election had violated Texas laws, but Coke’s supporters took over the state capitol and inaugurated him in January 1874. Over the next few years he helped lead a Democratic resurgence in the state that broke down many Reconstruction policies that protected Black civil rights in the 1870s.

Coke resigned his governor’s seat in 1876 when he won election to the U.S. Senate. He served three consecutive terms, retiring after his third term expired in 1895. He retired in Waco and died on May 14, 1897. He was married Mary Evans Horne and had at least four children. Coke is buried in Oakwood Cemetery in Waco, Texas.
Richard Coke belonged to the following social groups:

Located in Simpson County, Mississippi, Westville was founded in 1824 and served as the county seat from 1824 until 1900, when it was replaced by Mendenhall. It was incorporated in 1836. Presently, Westville is a deserted town with few or no remaining inhabitants. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Texas, Nacogdoches County was founded in 1837 and its county seat is Nacogdoches, Texas. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: "The crime of intentionally killing a person." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of using legal authority to catch and take someone to a place where the person may be accused of a crime." (CD)
"An amount of money set as a reward," typically to incentivize capturing a fugitive from justice. (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of making someone return for trial to another country or state where he or she has been accused of doing something illegal." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., an official whose job is to be in charge of performing the orders of the law courts and making certain that the laws are obeyed within a particular county." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who works in an office, dealing with records or performing general office duties." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A court of equity in some US states." (Cambridge Dictionary)

Operating at the state level, the Executive department of the State of Texas consists of the governor, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, agriculture commissioner, state comptroller of accounts, land commissioner, education board, Texas Railroad Commission, and attorney general. Each official is elected for a four-year term and is appointed duties pertaining to state regulations. (Wikipedia)

div.p:
OFFICE OF Circuit Clerk
OF
Simpson County.
Westville, Miss., July 27# 1874

Hon A K Davis, Lieut Gov.
Acting Governor of Mississippi

Sir—I inclose herewith a true copy of a letter received by me from the Sheriff of Nacagdoches County Texas. The party therein refered to is evidently Jno Spradley (who you have heretofore offered a reward for, for the mur-der of Jno & James Hays of this County) as I have never written to him concerning any other party. We therefore ask that you make a requisition on the Gov. of Texas for his arrest and delivery to the Sheriff of this County at as early a day as practicable. Such crimes are getting to be so frequent in this Country, that all good Citizens are getting anxious to see the laws properly enforced.

L, A, Mc"Caskill
Circuit & Chancery Clerk
Simpson County
Mississippi
You will see from the copy herewith inclosed, in what county in Texas the party is & you can instruct the Gov. of that State accordingly.
div.note: L. A. McCaskill, not L. A. M. Caskill.

div.p:
500 reward for Jno & Wm Spradley
July 3d" 1874
Murder of James R and A. J. Hays Simpson County 24th" May 1874
Write to L. A. McCaskill for affidavit to send with requisition on Gov of Texas
